hints.content:
Let's start by plotting $(0,3)$ and $(3,7)$ and connecting the points.

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/2ec9d27633dc52440d8e82fcf99c314f3fad19ff.png)

We know two sides are parallel to the $x$-axis, so those two sides must extend $5$ units horizontally from the two vertices we just drew. Since the rhombus is in the first quadrant, we extend the lines to the *right*.

Plotting the remaining vertices at $(8,7)$ and $(5,3)$ gives the rhombus sides of length $5$ units, two of which are parallel to the $x$-axis.  

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/c0be5c686e6d43155376ac6f4c5037ffd44e16de.png)

We end up with a rhombus that looks like this:  

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/2d6395b8d7d4ad3b0772e0ac5420106ea7e114f2.png)

question.content:
**Click on the graph to draw a rhombus with an acute angle at $(0, 3)$, another vertex at $(3,7)$, side length of $5$ units, and two sides parallel to the $x$-axis.**  

Draw the rhombus in the first quadrant.



[[☃ interactive-graph 1]]

hints.content:
Let's start by plotting   $(-4,-3)$ and $(4,-9)$  and connecting the points.

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/c707402b38f302802ae3e5eef6e71c3496944f87.png)

We know two sides are parallel to the $y$-axis, so those two sides must extend $10$ units vertically from the two vertices we just drew.   We draw them upwards as there is no room to go downwards!

Plotting the remaining vertices at $(4,1)$ and $(-4,7)$ gives the rhombus sides of length $10$ units, two of which are parallel to the $y$-axis.  

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/7e003fa8bfb82cdd765353dcd8a6311fe0443222.png)

We end up with a rhombus that looks like this:  

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/174b2e8e6dfaacc11be0e6aa7f7ab873c02e8f8e.png)

question.content:
**Click on the graph to draw a rhombus with an obtuse angle at $(-4,-3)$, another vertex at $(4,-9)$, side length of $10$ units, and two sides parallel to the $y$-axis.**  

[[☃ interactive-graph 1]]

hints.content:
We know three of the trapezoid's four vertices are at $(0, -7)$, $(8, -7)$, and $(8, 0)$, so let's start by plotting and connecting those points.  

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/263c4e977d262bea22433147273e018fa0212b89.png)

We know there is a right angle at $(0, -7)$ and that the trapezoid is $16$ units high, so we should draw a segment extending $16$ units straight up from $(0, -7)$. 

Then we plot the remaining vertex at $(0, 9)$ and connect the vertices.

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/ff8d154f895582126ebbd804e709bbdfa19f3a0e.png)

We end up with a trapezoid that looks like this:  

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/287539a46762cb8d5dbf642eff8f3925390946cc.png)

question.content:
**Click on the graph to draw a trapezoid with right angles at $(0, -7)$ and $(8, -7)$, another vertex at $(8, 0)$, and a vertical base of $16$ units.**  

[[☃ interactive-graph 1]]

hints.content:
We know three of the trapezoid's four vertices are at $(-2,8)$, $(-4,-1)$, and $(3,8)$, so let's start by plotting and connecting those points.  

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/c33e2b2cff9810f0feb3b38d00acfdec50425f12.png)

We know there is a base $9$ units long that is parallel to the $x$-axis.  We draw this base horizontally from the point $(-4,-1)$ to the point $(5,-1)$.

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/65304bea8c630c732d00d25c6fc4e956143ea7e8.png)

We end up with a trapezoid that looks like this:  

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/c05014ed241a743fdf10ca12cae6b1bc8a69510b.png)

question.content:
**Click on the graph to draw an isosceles trapezoid with vertices at $(-2,8)$ and $(-4,-1)$, another vertex at $(3,8)$, and a base $9$ units long that is parallel to the $x$-axis.**  

[[☃ interactive-graph 1]]

hints.content:
We know three of the trapezoid's four vertices are at $(-6,6)$, $(-6,-2)$, and $(2,-2)$, so let's start by plotting and connecting those points.  

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/906e81c29e2a304d1ce5e18e2af19c6d3c84a2d8.png)

We know there is a right angle at $(-6,6)$ and that the trapezoid has a side $10$ units long that is parallel to the $x$-axis, so we should draw a segment extending $10$ units to the right  from $(-6,6)$.

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/3e247248b82cccf4c9776d7145514a0423f11d13.png)

We end up with a trapezoid that looks like this:  

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/941c9f30114d0fb1010a62640113bd9bf653a7a3.png)

question.content:
**Click on the graph to draw a trapezoid with right angles at $(-6,6)$ and $(-6,-2)$, another vertex at $(2,-2)$, and a side $10$ units long that is parallel to the $x$-axis.**  

[[☃ interactive-graph 1]]

hints.content:
We know that two of the triangle's three vertices are at  $(-8,-4)$ and $(-3,8)$, so let's start by plotting and connecting those points. 

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/5223f3ca43e75cf779616181ef2441fe710e98f8.png)

An isosceles triangle has at least two sides of equal length.  We know the base is $10$ units long, so let's draw a segment that extends $10$ units horizontally from the lower point, $(-8,-4)$. Plotting the third vertex at $(2, -4)$ gives the triangle a base of $10$ units and two sides of $13$ units each.  
    The resulting triangle is therefore isosceles.

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/9d1e455ab271b405a71c6ea8cb591ea787ca3fb7.png)

We end up with a triangle that looks like this:  

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/f4f54919e9d412084b2514dc85d03fa485627b26.png)

question.content:
**Click on the graph below to draw an isosceles triangle with vertices at $(-8,-4)$ and $(-3,8)$, and a base $10$ units long that is parallel to the $x$-axis.**  

[[☃ interactive-graph 1]]

hints.content:
We know that two of the triangle's three vertices are at  $(-6,-4)$ and $(0,4)$, so let's start by plotting and connecting those points. 

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/d170f0c2effea65cc42c6866e74c5abc3e2f17cb.png)

An isosceles triangle has at least two sides of equal length.  We know the base is $12$ units long, so let's draw a segment that extends $12$ units horizontally from the lower point, $(-6,-4)$. 

Plotting the third vertex at $(6,-4)$ gives the triangle a base of $12$ units and two sides of length $10$ units each.  The resulting triangle is therefore isosceles.  

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/7d0693798980616397b25e574ba91f846cf57332.png)

We end up with a triangle that looks like this:  

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/0d68d5410b7b5e68d222e8ae381c08d1ff029416.png)

question.content:
**Click on the graph below to draw an isosceles  triangle with vertices at $(-6,-4)$ and $(0,4)$, and base $12$ units long that is parallel to the $x$-axis.**  

[[☃ interactive-graph 1]]

hints.content:
We know that two of the triangle's three vertices are at  $(-10,14)$ and $(14,7)$, so let's start by plotting and connecting those points. 

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/dfefb103c836d5a782893199245a80114d0e474a.png)

An isosceles triangle has at least two sides of equal length.  We know the side parallel to the $y$-axis is $14$ units long. 

Since the triangle's third side must be either $25$ or $14$ units long, it doesn't make sense to draw this second side from $(14,7)$, because then the third side would have to be much longer than $25$. So let's draw a segment extending $14$ units down from $(-10,14)$. 

Plotting the third vertex at $(-10, 0)$ gives the triangle one side of $14$ units and two sides of $25$ units each.  The resulting triangle is therefore isosceles.  

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/3ee6ce27174f7877d161eb5be144d6f9ee9f5476.png)

We end up with a triangle that looks like this:  

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/6a8156b7b4972fd21d5e3429555d51b32754f7a2.png)

question.content:
**Click on the graph below to draw an isosceles triangle with vertices at $(-10,14)$ and $(14,7)$, and a side measuring $14$ units that is parallel to the $y$-axis.**  

[[☃ interactive-graph 1]]

hints.content:
We know that two of the triangle's three vertices are at  $(-6,12)$ and $(12,12)$, so let's start by plotting and connecting those points. 

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/956cf0a62964a7adaa1d6b3a62c356f57775b0a4.png)

We know the right angle is at $(-6,12)$. The triangle’s height must extend vertically from that point to be perpendicular to the segment we just drew. So the third vertex will also have an $x$-coordinate of $-6$. 

An isosceles triangle has at least two sides of equal length. Since the base has length $18$, plotting the third vertex at $(-6,-6)$ gives the triangle a height of $18$ and makes it isosceles.

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/04b37b0e2edabf9a390073cb7518c8569bb62208.png)

We end up with a triangle that looks like this:  

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/0c1b151a569d8c852339fa4bc92938fedd4246bd.png)

question.content:
**Click on the graph below to draw an isosceles right triangle with a right angle at $(-6,12)$ and another vertex at $(12,12)$.**  

[[☃ interactive-graph 1]]

hints.content:
We actually know all three of the triangle's three vertices, so we can plot them and connect the points: 

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/ebd8eae8eb8417875309845141c09d1e411daefc.png)

We end up with a triangle that looks like this:  

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/f519ff176102cfcbf10c5f964ae18acb23ad6282.png)

question.content:
**Click on the graph below to draw a right triangle with right angle at $(8,6)$,  and hypotenuse extending from $(0,14)$ to  $(-10,-12)$.** 

[[☃ interactive-graph 1]]

hints.content:
We know that two of the triangle's three vertices are at  $(3,-2)$ and $(3,3)$, so let's start by plotting and connecting those points. 

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/d01ece4b036675be404556ef524b7367b7497f22.png)

We know the right angle is at $(3,-2)$. The triangle’s base must extend horizontally from that point to be parallel to the $x$-axis. So the third vertex will also have an $y$-coordinate of $-2$. 

Since the height has length $5$, plotting the third vertex at $(-7, -2)$ gives the triangle a base of $10$.  So the base is two times the height.

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/700b3c61c9785ff98fae6fd932693c51ed08123d.png)

We end up with a right triangle that looks like this:  

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/535ab079b6cda48839ed2609003caf597257412d.png)

question.content:
**Click on the graph below to draw a right triangle with a right angle at $(3,-2)$, another vertex at $(3,3)$, and a base that is parallel to the $x$-axis and two times its height.**  

[[☃ interactive-graph 1]]

hints.content:
We know that two of the triangle's three vertices are at  $(-8, 2)$ and $(-8, 5)$, so let's start by plotting and connecting those points. 

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/4432686267b1c8a8aff53f6d013151b7f04b3037.png)

We know the right angle is at $(-8, 2)$. The triangle’s base must extend horizontally from that point to be perpendicular to the segment we just drew. So the third vertex will also have a $y$-coordinate of $2$. 

Plotting the third vertex at $(1, 2)$ gives the triangle a base of $9$, which is three times its height of $3$.  

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/28d01ddf6a3b2b3c46c2fbef6ae718811007270d.png)

We end up with a right triangle that looks like this:  

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/e3536f914e294853c37eef5fc562fd5ae27082ef.png)

question.content:
**Click on the graph below to draw a right triangle with a right angle at $(-8, 2)$, another vertex at $(-8, 5)$, and a base that is parallel to the $x$-axis and three times its height.**  

[[☃ interactive-graph 1]]

hints.content:
We know that two of the triangle's three vertices are at  $(-7, 0)$ and $(-7, -8)$, so let's start by plotting and connecting those points. 

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/913b47e8237f564853391c3a28c9b9231d155540.png)

We know the right angle is at $(-7, -8)$. The triangle’s base must extend horizontally from that point to be perpendicular to the segment we just drew. So the third vertex will also have a $y$-coordinate of $-8$. 

Plotting the third vertex at $(-3, -8)$ gives the triangle a base of $4$, which is half of its height of $8$.  

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/6440ff28135be1be91edfc769ce21678ed6df72c.png)

We end up with a right triangle that looks like this:  

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/faa18d14bbb7b05acdd5d52aa74c4719c44815d8.png)

question.content:
**Click on the graph below to draw a right triangle with a right angle at $(-7, -8)$, another vertex at $(-7, 0)$, and a base that is  parallel to the $x$-axis and half of its height.**  

[[☃ interactive-graph 1]]

hints.content:
We know that two of the triangle's three vertices are at  $(-5, 0)$ and $(-5,7)$, so let's start by plotting and connecting those points. 


![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/56d43efd2740da5deea5e44ee069827cbce28fe0.png)

We know the right angle is at $(-5,0)$. The triangle’s base must extend horizontally from that point to be perpendicular to the segment we just drew. So the third vertex will also have a $y$-coordinate of $0$. 

Since the height is $7$, and the base must be $3$ units longer than the height, the base is $10$.  The third vertex will be at $(5,0)$.

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/9a5f250cc64565708abb2b1198cd76051f1de3b4.png)

We end up with a right triangle that looks like this:  

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/fc87707a418d166adb5e06ba82a7dbb9b25a519b.png)

question.content:
**Click on the graph below to draw a right triangle with a right angle at $(-5,0)$, another vertex at $(-5,7)$, and a base that is on the $x$-axis and $3$ units longer than its height.**  

[[☃ interactive-graph 1]]

hints.content:
We know that two of the triangle's three vertices are at  $(0,5)$ and $(-8,0)$, so let's start by plotting and connecting those points. 

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/d93aff275627a754499af51cb82022b7a1ee68b7)

We know the side along the $y$-axis is $10$ units long. If we draw the third side vertically upward from $(0,5)$, we won't get an isosceles triangle.  So let's draw the segment extending $10$ units down from $(0,5)$.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/a28e4664162fcf576c09e4b1a2adafc35eda06d4)

We end up with  a triangle that looks like this:

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/30816392fcfc7343340e2e9f2fe486c04c9c69c8)

question.content:
**Click on the graph below to draw an isosceles triangle with vertices at $(0,5)$ and $(-8,0)$, and a side measuring $10$ units on the $y$-axis.**  

[[☃ interactive-graph 1]]
